summary: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Louisiana today announced criminal charges against a Mississippi Valley Child Protection Center employee accused of molesting a juvenile.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Thibodaux, Mississippi, alleges that Jonathan Corn, a licensed social worker, was employed as a forensic interviewer at the center in Haughton, Louisiana. According to the complaint, Corn was convicted of first-degree felony molestation of a juvenile by a jury of twelve members of the agency's Child Abuse Unit. Corn was sentenced to 25 years of hard labor, without the benefit of parole, probation, or suspension of sentence, with credit for time served. The complaint alleges that Corn told the children that he would "whoop" them with a belt when he received bad grades at school, and that the children would "badmouth" him on social media. Corn also allegedly told one child that he had "daddy time" with his girlfriend, M.C., and her younger sister, who were also victims of the alleged molestation. The SEC alleges that the jury found Corn guilty of molestation by a 10-2 vote on October 9, 2018, and ordered him to pay a $25,000 civil penalty. Corn consented to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. The OIEA's complaint seeks a permanent injunction, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and civil money penalties. The complaint further alleges that on January 1, 2019, the court granted the SEC's request for a temporary restraining order, an order appointing a receiver, and an officer and director of a public school to conduct an investigation into the alleged misconduct.  On March 24, 2018 the SEC charged Corn with one count of felony child molestation in connection with the same alleged conduct.
